The sport is played in teams of 2 against 2 distributed around the net. Players on the same team stand side by side before the serve; once the ball is in play, players can move around the net. The ball must be hit every time. The ball is put into play by a serve that must bounce over the net to the opposing team. The receiving team can make up to 3 touches, alternating between the players, before returning the ball to the other team by bouncing it on the net. Note that the servers must be behind the service line for the service to be valid. A point is scored when the ball touches the ground or the ring of the net or when it bounces more than once on the net. A point is scored in all games, regardless of which team has possession of the serve. When a team scores a point, the service goes to them. With each service win, the serving player must alternate. The serving player must switch positions with his or her teammate on each serve, if the team holds it for several points. The match ends when a team reaches the designated number of points, typically 15 or 21 points, with at least a two-point difference. There are also variations for 2, 3 and 6 players.

The net is 3 feet in diameter and 8 inches high. The net is mounted on a ring divided into five parts and five removable legs for easy transportation. The tension of the net should be adjusted so that it is even over the entire surface. A ball dropped from a height of 5 feet from the ground should bounce approximately 20 inches from the net. The ball should be inflated to a circumference of 12 inches. A flat court (beach, grass, gym, etc.) of approximately 30 feet by 30 feet is recommended to have enough playing space without obstruction. There are no court boundaries. A service line 7 feet from the edge of the net or 8.5 feet from the center of the net should be drawn, if possible, to mark the service position
